title: Improving Text Classification with Penalized Logistic Regression
text: This analysis demonstrates how to improve prediction performance for a text classification task using TF-IDF features and a penalized logistic regression model (elastic net) in R.

title: Improving Text Classification with Penalized Logistic Regression
text: This analysis demonstrates how to improve prediction performance for a text classification task using TF-IDF features and a penalized logistic regression model (elastic net) in R.

title: Improving Text Classification with Penalized Logistic Regression
section: ðŸ“¥ Step 1: Load Required Libraries
text:
ðŸ“¥ Step 1: Load Required Libraries
We load tidyverse tools for data manipulation, tidymodels for modeling, and textrecipes for text preprocessing.

library(tidyverse)

â”€â”€ Attaching core tidyverse packages â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse 2.0.0 â”€â”€
âœ” dplyr     1.1.4     âœ” readr     2.1.5
âœ” forcats   1.0.0     âœ” stringr   1.5.1
âœ” ggplot2   3.5.2     âœ” tibble    3.2.1
âœ” lubridate 1.9.4     âœ” tidyr     1.3.1
âœ” purrr     1.0.4     
â”€â”€ Conflicts â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse_conflicts() â”€â”€
âœ– dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
âœ– dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
â„¹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(tidymodels)

â”€â”€ Attaching packages â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidymodels 1.3.0 â”€â”€
âœ” broom        1.0.8     âœ” rsample      1.3.0
âœ” dials        1.4.0     âœ” tune         1.3.0
âœ” infer        1.0.8     âœ” workflows    1.2.0
âœ” modeldata    1.4.0     âœ” workflowsets 1.1.0
âœ” parsnip      1.3.1     âœ” yardstick    1.3.2

â”€â”€ Conflicts â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidymodels_conflicts() â”€â”€
âœ– scales::discard() masks purrr::discard()
âœ– dplyr::filter()   masks stats::filter()

âœ– dplyr::lag()      masks stats::lag()
âœ– yardstick::spec() masks readr::spec()
âœ– recipes::step()   masks stats::step()

library(textrecipes)
library(workflows)
library(stopwords)

title: Improving Text Classification with Penalized Logistic Regression
section: ðŸ“„ Step 2: Load and Prepare the Data
text:
ðŸ“„ Step 2: Load and Prepare the Data
We load a labeled corpus of 200 short documents and convert the target label to a factor for classification. We split the data 70/30 for training and testing.

data <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/datageneration/knowledgemining/refs/heads/master/data/km_sample_corpus_200.csv") %>%
  mutate(label = factor(label))

Rows: 200 Columns: 2
â”€â”€ Column specification â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€

set.seed(123)
split <- initial_split(data, prop = 0.7, strata = label)
train_data <- training(split)
test_data  <- testing(split)

title: Improving Text Classification with Penalized Logistic Regression
section: âœ‚ï¸ Step 3: Text Preprocessing with TF-IDF
text:
âœ‚ï¸ Step 3: Text Preprocessing with TF-IDF
We create a recipe to: - Tokenize the text - Remove stopwords - Keep the 500 most frequent tokens - Convert tokens into TF-IDF weighted features
This enriches the feature set and improves classification performance.

rec <- recipe(label ~ text, data = train_data) %>%
  step_tokenize(text) %>%
  step_stopwords(text) %>%
  step_tokenfilter(text, max_tokens = 500) %>%
  step_tfidf(text)

title: Improving Text Classification with Penalized Logistic Regression
section: ðŸŒ² Step 4: Define Penalized Logistic Regression Model
text:
ðŸŒ² Step 4: Define Penalized Logistic Regression Model
We use multinom_reg() from parsnip with glmnet engine to perform logistic regression with elastic net regularization. The penalty (Î») and mixture (Î±) parameters will be tuned.

lr_spec <- multinom_reg(penalty = tune(), mixture = tune()) %>%
  set_engine("glmnet") %>%
  set_mode("classification")

title: Improving Text Classification with Penalized Logistic Regression
section: ðŸ”§ Step 5: Workflow Setup
text:
ðŸ”§ Step 5: Workflow Setup
We combine the recipe and model into a single workflow, which simplifies the training and tuning process.

library(workflows)
wf <- workflow() %>%
  add_recipe(rec) %>%
  add_model(lr_spec)

title: Improving Text Classification with Penalized Logistic Regression
section: ðŸ” Step 6: Cross-Validation
text:
ðŸ” Step 6: Cross-Validation
We perform 5-fold cross-validation to robustly estimate model performance during tuning.

set.seed(123)
cv_folds <- vfold_cv(train_data, v = 5, strata = label)

title: Improving Text Classification with Penalized Logistic Regression
section: ðŸŽ¯ Step 7: Define Hyperparameter Grid
text:
ðŸŽ¯ Step 7: Define Hyperparameter Grid
We define a grid of 25 combinations by varying: - penalty: strength of regularization (log scale from 10^-4 to 1) - mixture: 0 = ridge, 1 = lasso, in between = elastic net

lr_grid <- grid_regular(
  penalty(range = c(-4, 0)),
  mixture(range = c(0, 1)),
  levels = 5
)

title: Improving Text Classification with Penalized Logistic Regression
section: ðŸ” Step 8: Tune the Model
text:
ðŸ” Step 8: Tune the Model
We tune the model using the workflow and grid defined above. Accuracy and Kappa are used as metrics.

set.seed(123)
tune_results <- tune_grid(
  wf,
  resamples = cv_folds,
  grid = lr_grid,
  metrics = metric_set(accuracy, kap)
)

title: Improving Text Classification with Penalized Logistic Regression
section: âœ… Step 9: Select Best Model
text:
âœ… Step 9: Select Best Model
We select the best combination of hyperparameters based on highest accuracy.

best_params <- select_best(tune_results, metric = "accuracy")

title: Improving Text Classification with Penalized Logistic Regression
section: ðŸ—ï¸ Step 10: Finalize and Train Model
text:
ðŸ—ï¸ Step 10: Finalize and Train Model
We finalize the workflow with the best hyperparameters and fit the model on the full training dataset.

final_wf <- finalize_workflow(wf, best_params)
final_fit <- final_wf %>% fit(data = train_data)

Warning: max_tokens was set to 500, but only 137 was available and selected.

title: Improving Text Classification with Penalized Logistic Regression
section: ðŸ“ˆ Step 11: Predict and Evaluate on Test Set
text:
ðŸ“ˆ Step 11: Predict and Evaluate on Test Set
We generate predictions and evaluate them using accuracy and Kappa score.

final_preds <- predict(final_fit, new_data = test_data) %>%
  bind_cols(test_data)

final_metrics <- metric_set(accuracy, kap)(final_preds, truth = label, estimate = .pred_class)
final_metrics

title: Improving Text Classification with Penalized Logistic Regression
section: âœ… Summary: How We Improved Prediction
text:
âœ… Summary: How We Improved Prediction
Compared to the earlier Random Forest approach, this model: - Used a penalized logistic regression, which is better suited for sparse high-dimensional data like TF-IDF - Tuned regularization parameters, improving generalization - Used more features (500 tokens vs.Â 100), capturing more context
This workflow is more interpretable, efficient, and predictive for TF-IDF-based text classification.

title: Assignment 03
section: 7. Create a corpus using government documents selected from the govinfo.gov website
text:
7. Create a corpus using government documents selected from the govinfo.gov website
To avoid replicating earlier examples, we use a different Foreign Affairs-related document titled:

â€œA bill to establish the Office of Press Freedom, to create press freedom curriculum at the National Foreign Affairs Training Centerâ€¦â€

This document is selected from the govinfo.gov dataset and will be downloaded and processed into a corpus.

library(jsonlite)
library(pdftools)

Using poppler version 25.02.0

library(quanteda)

# Load metadata from JSON
gf_list1 <- read_json("https://github.com/datageneration/datamethods/raw/refs/heads/master/webdata/govinfo-search-results-2024-10-13T07_18_29.json")
govfiles3 <- bind_rows(gf_list1$resultSet)

# Find document about Press Freedom
doc_index <- which(grepl("Press Freedom", govfiles3$title))
url <- govfiles3$pdfLink[doc_index]
id <- govfiles3$index[doc_index]

# Set your actual directory path
save_dir <- "D:/UTD/Courses/Spring 2025/EPPS 6323 Knowledge Mining/assignments/KM_Assignment04/"

# Create directory if it doesn't exist
dir.create(save_dir, recursive = TRUE, showWarnings = FALSE)

# Use only the first matching document (in case there are multiple)
destfile <- paste0(save_dir, "govfiles_", id[1], ".pdf")

# Download PDF
download.file(url[1], destfile, mode = "wb")

# Extract text and build corpus
txt <- pdf_text(destfile)
full_text <- paste(txt, collapse = "\n")
corp <- corpus(full_text)

# Tokenize and plot
dfm_doc <- corp %>%
  tokens(remove_punct = TRUE) %>%
  tokens_remove(stopwords("english")) %>%
  dfm() %>%
  dfm_trim(min_termfreq = 3)

textplot_wordcloud(dfm_doc)

title: Assignment 02
section: 5) Explore Relationship Between Tondu and Other Variables
text:
5) Explore Relationship Between Tondu and Other Variables
We ran a linear regression to examine how Tondu is affected by predictors like gender, party support (DPP), age, income, education, ethnic identity, and economic perception.
The regression model helps quantify which variables have significant effects on Tondu.

TEDS_2016_cleaned$female <- as.factor(TEDS_2016_cleaned$female)
TEDS_2016_cleaned$DPP <- as.factor(TEDS_2016_cleaned$DPP)
TEDS_2016_cleaned$Taiwanese <- as.factor(TEDS_2016_cleaned$Taiwanese)
TEDS_2016_cleaned$Econ_worse <- as.factor(TEDS_2016_cleaned$Econ_worse)

model <- lm(Tondu ~ female + DPP + age + income + edu + Taiwanese + Econ_worse, data = TEDS_2016_cleaned)
summary(model)

Visualization of Relationships
We used boxplots to explore how the variable Tondu (support for unification or independence) varies by categorical variables such as gender and DPP affiliation.

The first plot shows differences in Tondu scores between male and female respondents.
The second plot compares Tondu scores for people who do or do not support the DPP.


ggplot(TEDS_2016_cleaned, aes(x = female, y = Tondu, fill = female)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  labs(title = "Tondu by Gender", x = "Female", y = "Tondu") +
  theme_minimal()







ggplot(TEDS_2016_cleaned, aes(x = DPP, y = Tondu, fill = DPP)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  labs(title = "Tondu by DPP Affiliation", x = "DPP", y = "Tondu") +
  theme_minimal()

title: Assignment 02
section: 6) Explore the votetsai Variable
text:
6) Explore the votetsai Variable
The variable votetsai shows whether a respondent voted for Tsai Ing-wen. A bar chart helps us understand how common support for Tsai is among the respondents.

ggplot(na.omit(TEDS_2016_cleaned), aes(x = factor(votetsai))) +
  geom_bar(fill = "steelblue") +
  labs(title = "Distribution of votetsai", x = "Vote for Tsai Ing-wen", y = "Count") +
  theme_minimal()

title: Assignment 02
section: 7) Frequency Table and Bar Chart for Tondu
text:
7) Frequency Table and Bar Chart for Tondu
To better understand the distribution of political preferences in Taiwan, we recoded the numeric Tondu variable into labeled categories such as: - â€œUnification nowâ€, â€œIndependence nowâ€, â€œStatus quo foreverâ€, etc.
Then we used a bar chart to display the frequency of each preference. This helps visually compare how common each political stance is in the dataset.

TEDS_2016$Tondu <- factor(TEDS_2016$Tondu,
                          labels = c("Unification now",
                                     "Status quo, unif. in future",
                                     "Status quo, decide later",
                                     "Status quo forever",
                                     "Status quo, indep. in future",
                                     "Independence now",
                                     "No response"))

table(TEDS_2016$Tondu)


             Unification now  Status quo, unif. in future 
                          27                          180 
    Status quo, decide later           Status quo forever 
                         546                          328 
Status quo, indep. in future             Independence now 
                         380                          108 
                 No response 
                         121 

ggplot(data.frame(Tondu = TEDS_2016$Tondu), aes(x = Tondu)) +
  geom_bar(fill = "coral") +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Bar Chart of Tondu Responses", x = "Tondu", y = "Count") +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))
